ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I had no idea philosophy of probability was even a thing, so I really felt like I got a deep dive into this area of the discipline.
different understanding of probability and different types of probability
Better thinking and reasoning skills; subjective and objective probabilities & their respective frameworks

- Knowledge of the most prominent ways of interpreting probability, their strengths, weaknesses, and classification relative to one another
- Perplexity, along with professional philosophers, as to whether any interpretation is sufficiently coherent for unqualified acceptance
- Practice writing analytical, objection-response philosophy papers

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The material could have been more interesting at times.
I felt as though the progression of topics built upon one another well and I learned a lot through the course

I liked the method of having students do in class presentations on readings. It allowed me to get oriented on readings I didnt go super deep into, and really get to know the reading that I presented on.
Strengths: extremely well-organized. Weaknesses: would be better if we have more time for discussions

The readings sometimes required specialized technical knowledge, but they were explained thoroughly and made approachable in class. Higher-level concepts and distinctions became very clear over time, like the subjective-objective divide, and the general definitions of each interpretation--a good introduction. More specific problems and distinctions were tougher to master, but that would make sense given my unfamiliarity with the subject. One note on the explanations is that some examples--like the often-cited decay of a radioactive atom--would have been easier to understand if I had more background knowledge in physics (even after I took two semesters of intro physics at Yale).

The best discussions were those in which students took the most active role, particularly frequentism and the applications unit at the end. The first (real) class, on the history of probability, seemed slightly extraneous to the more analytical content we worked with later, but it was still interesting. 

The decision to swap out the problem set for a third paper was unexpected, and I would be curious to see what a problem set might look like, but the paper feedback was very helpful and I'm ultimately glad to have had the extra practice with a paper instead.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Maybe? Only if they're interested in the material.
yes; if you like math/probability and philosophy you will enjoy the course a lot
Yes - the topics are hard to wrap your head around but if you find it interesting its very rewarding.

Absolutely, yes. More specialized philosophy seminars like this one are great; they usually draw good classmates and it's always fun to work with contemporary readings/papers. This class in particular was no exception, and it was fun to think hard enough to write papers in an area of philosophy that I wouldn't usually explore. The class itself, thanks to Dr. Meehan, struck a good balance between complicated arguments and simple explanations. And probability is something we often take for granted, so it's ripe for philosophical examination.
Absolutely, yes. Such important and under discussed topics, if a little niche at times -- applications are wide ranging though!
